original_title: Sri Lanka to import 15,000mt of maize for poultry feed
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The Sri Lanka State Trading (General) Corporation will import 15,000 metric tons of maize to address the shortage of raw materials required for the production of poultry feed, a cabinet statement said.
Insufficient stocks of maize in the open market have led to a scarcity in animal feed, and pushed meat and egg prices up.
“As a temporary measure for this, the Department of Animal Production and Health has given the necessary licence to import 15,000 metric tons of maize from registered foreign suppliers.”
Sri Lanka’s chicken meat and egg prices are generally higher than the world due to import licensing on maize which has pushed up production costs.
Sri Lanka Trade Minister threatens egg farmers amid import controls on maize
Sri Lanka eyes 250,000MT maize production for Thriposha, other animal feed
Maize taxes are only cut to make Thriposha, a supplement for children facing malnutrition.
Maize is a staple input in the livestock feed industry and maize-based food items such as Thriposha and Samaposha.

Sri Lanka produces about 250,000 metric tons of maize and has a national requirement of 600,000MT. According to reports the poultry feed requirement is around 400,000 metric ton, the dairy sector consumes another 200,000 metric ton of maize as cattle feed. (Colombo/Dec21/2023)
